text: Good morning everyone! a newbie question, I need to search a text (MPS) file to find some key word to locate the section “RHS”; then check the next line to see if that line has the word “obj”. If there is, then remove that line and save the file. Since the file is large, e.g., 30 mb, what is the most efficient way to implement this task? Thanks!

elements.text: Good morning everyone! a newbie question, I need to search a text (MPS) file to find some key word to locate the section “RHS”; then check the next line to see if that line has the word “obj”. If there is, then remove that line and save the file. Since the file is large, e.g., 30 mb, what is the most efficient way to implement this task? Thanks!

text: Is the keyword guaranteed to be on one single line, and not split across two lines?

elements.text: Is the keyword guaranteed to be on one single line, and not split across two lines?

text: RHS the only word on that line, starting the section. Then the next line is the first row in this section with multiple words. I just need to see if the first line has “obj” and then remove that line.

elements.text: RHS the only word on that line, starting the section. Then the next line is the first row in this section with multiple words. I just need to see if the first line has “obj” and then remove that line.

text: Ah, that should be pretty easy then.

elements.text: Ah, that should be pretty easy then.
glad to hear

text:
Something like
```function foo(inpath, outpath)
    infile = open(inpath)
    outfile = open(outpath, "w")
    skip_next = false
    for line in eachline(file)
        if line == "RHS"
            skip_next = true
        else
            skip_next = false
            if skip_next
                continue
            end
        end
        println(outfile, line)
    end
end```

text: If it's that small, you can load the entire file into a vector and search for the bytes "\nRHS\n", to find the position

elements.text: If it's that small, you can load the entire file into a vector and search for the bytes "\nRHS\n", to find the position

text: Then you can search for `obj` in the next line, and if you find it, print out the vector before that line, and after that line

text:
Does this work? DIdn't check it
```function foo(inpath, outpath)
    data = open(read, inpath)
    range = findfirst(r"RHS\n[^\n]*obj", s)
    if range === nothing
        cp(inpath, outpath)
    end
    open(outpath) do writer
        write(@view data[1:first(range)+3])
        write(@view data[last(range):end])
    end
end```

    if range === nothing

text: Thanks <@U7HAYKY9X> It will take me a while to understand the code.  I will try both of them and let you know the efficiency difference.

elements.text: Thanks

text:
OK, tested it a bit. Try this:
```function foo(inpath, outpath)
    data = open(io -> String(read(io)), inpath)
    range = findfirst(r"RHS\n[^\n]*obj[^\n]*\n", data)
    if range === nothing
        cp(inpath, outpath)
    end
    open(outpath, "w") do writer
        write(writer, @view data[1:first(range)+3])
        write(writer, @view data[last(range)+1:end])
    end
end```

elements.text: OK, tested it a bit. Try this:

function foo(inpath, outpath)
    data = open(io -> String(read(io)), inpath)
    range = findfirst(r"RHS\n[^\n]*obj[^\n]*\n", data)
    if range === nothing
        cp(inpath, outpath)
    end
    open(outpath, "w") do writer
        write(writer, @view data[1:first(range)+3])
        write(writer, @view data[last(range)+1:end])
    end
end
Thanks! trying it out.
